Fields.DialogueText: Still dusting? I thought the cleaning detail was finished up for today.
I can't stop until everything is in order.
I know that, but you can always take a break. A little bit of dust never killed anyone.
Actually... it can. Which is why I can never let it happen again.
Missy, what do you mean?
Years ago, we were practicing with the guns... and something went wrong. Ol' Number Two blew up, and a lot of good folks died that day.
I see. So that's why...?
Beauty and elegance matter, to be sure, but it's more than that. My own sailors died, because I got lazy and didn't pay enough attention. What if it happens again?

Fields.MenuText: It wasn't your fault. Accidents happen to everyone, whether you want them or not.
It won't. You won't let us down.
You need to forgive yourself, Missy. I'm sure your sailors never blamed you to begin with.

Fields.DialogueText: Fault or not, I am still responsible. If it happened again... I just could never forgive myself.
Thank you, Captain. That helps a lot.
It's tough, though. Could you really forgive me, if something like that happened to you?
Anyway, you'll need to set aside your cleaning for now. We're coming in range with a pack of Morganas.
But I'm not finished yet! What if...?
Missy, I know that you accept nothing but perfection. But sometimes, we just have to make the best of things as they are.
I'll try my best. All gun crews to their stations! Time to sink some more monsters!
@BATTLE
The fact that you're worried so much shows that you're sincere in your dedication to your duties. So yes, I would forgive you.
This doesn't look good. What can our reconnaissance tell us about the blockade, Missy?
The Morganas have really fortified this line. It'll be tough to break through.
We can't make our rendezvous on the other side unless we do.
Don't worry, Captain. I said it would be tough, but I am well equipped for the challenge. What are your orders?

Fields.MenuText: Is the ship ready for battle?
Push through hard and fast. There's no time to waste.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm feeling pretty good about it, now that I've finished my cleaning rounds.
Got it. They'll regret trying to hold Mighty Miss back with a mere log jam.
This is it, Captain! We're almost there.
Right. Everyone, get ready.
@BATTLE
Good. Glad to-
I'll have more to fix after the battle, though.
One job at a time, okay?
Whew! Feels like a hot one today!
It certainly is, so do what every Southern Belle knows to do. Stay in the shade!
Shouldn't I be saying that to you?
Whatever might you mean? I am keeping my skin spotless thanks to my parasol.
That covers your body, but not your ship. I almost burnt myself on one of your rails earlier.
You must be imagining things, Captain. Like one of those mirages you see in a desert...

Fields.MenuText: Aren't those supposed to make you imagine refreshing things, not something even warmer?
I'm telling you, you are the hottest thing at sea right now.
Really, are you sure you feel okay? I'm just a little worried.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you implying that I'm the one seeing mirages? Why, such cheek! And from an officer! Captain, I don't mind telling you I'm a little bit scandalized.
Why, Captain, I thought we were only friends! Ha ha ha!
Oh, that's nice of you, but you don't need to worry. My metal parts are boiling hot, to be sure, but I've learned to separate that feeling from how I feel in this body, to a degree.
In any case, you make a valid point. I probably should do something to cool my ship self down a little - if not for me, then for the crew.
Not the worst idea - though the damage may already be done for today.
Nothing is impossible with enough effort!
@BATTLE
Uh-huh.
Interesting. There's a lot to learn about Belles.
Though, actually, let's hang onto the heat - I need all the energy I can get if we want to stop those Morganas up ahead.
Captain, are you busy?
Always... but no more than usual. What is it?
I'm trying to find a way to cool off my main body on sunny days like this, but I'm having trouble figuring out what to do. A penny for your thoughts?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you should talk with the other Belles. One of them might have already come up with an approach.
Well, your parasol keeps your Belle self cool - perhaps you could draw on its design?
I'm sorry, but I can't come up with anything.

Fields.DialogueText: Not a bad idea.
A splendid suggestion! A giant parasol extension above me would solve the problem, and give my ship a rather elegant flair, if I do say so.
That's all right. We're bound to get cooler days sooner than later... and I'll likely be yearning for these lovely hot days to return.
Actually, I just thought of something - what if I slap some white paint over everything? Plus, it would make me an absolute vision as a showboat!
I think we're fairly committed to haze gray - but washing it all down might help, I guess. I don't object if you want to try.
Thanks, Captain. You're a good friend.
Another raggedy batch... If only those nasty clouts could cool off a bit themselves.
@BATTLE
That wasn't... quite what I had in mind.
*ALARM*
Mississippi, why are you painting stripes on that pole? If the command does an inspection...
Oh, this is just for a new act I thought we could use for the show.
What's that?
One of the old classics - a barbershop quartet!
Oh? Well, that would be unique. Have you found anyone interested? It takes four people for a quartet, after all.
No... but maybe I'll find some brave songbirds somewhere...
Good luck with that. But... okay, listen, on the subject of barbers-
No need to hold your horses! Ask away.
Well, I've never seen you get your hair cut as long as we've been working together, but it still looks perfect. Is it something unique for Belles?
That's a secret! But maybe you could use some attention yourself, Captain. Wait, I know!
Now what?
Why don't I find a new style for you? Head to toe... it'll look dashing when I'm through.

Fields.MenuText: First of all, have you done this before?
I've lived my whole life looking like about a buck fifty, and I'm okay with that.
Thanks, but I can handle that myself.

Fields.DialogueText: I told you, that's a secret. Now, then, let me take a look...
There's a first time for everything!
Come now, Captain. If you try to do an amateurish attempt yourself, it will just make things worse.
Just be careful, please?
Don't you fret, there are no finer hands than mine...
Oopsie? What was the ''oopsie'' for?
Oh, nothing. Ummm, I think I sense Morganas approaching. We'd better get ready for combat!
Wait, Missy! What happened? Am I presentable?
@BATTLE
It's kind of important for you to answer my question right now.
That fails to reassure me.
... I don't have a choice, do I?
Except... Oh... Oopsie!
Oh, look! I just happen to have scissors handy!
Why would you-
Shush and sit down. I'll have you looking like a million dollars in no time.
Good news, Captain! Our troubles are a thing of the past.
What, did the war finally end?
No, but I have found a solution to the heat. Fresh, home-squeezed lemonade!
Oh, nice. Did you make it yourself?
Yes, just an hour ago. How about a tall glass?
I won't say no to that. *sip*
Well, how was it?

Fields.MenuText: I prefer orange juice. It's a little sweeter.
The taste was a little sour, but I liked the chill.
Wonderful!

Fields.DialogueText: I'll see if I can procure some fresh oranges the next time we're on shore leave, then.
Well, of course it's sour. But you're not wrong, in this weather, the cold factor is the most valuable ingredient.
Splendid! This is my own secret recipe.
You know, it's kind of funny how nobody will eat a lemon on its own, yet we all love lemonade.
I guess that it is kind of like the sun. While it can be unbearable at times, if you have a bit of shade around you - it can be fully appreciated.
That... makes a lot of sense.
On days like this, it's best to just watch the clouds go by, listen to the wind blow, and wish that those Morganas on the horizon weren't there...
Yeah, it sure... what?!
Well, we needed to get a little exercise anyway, I suppose. Hot day or not, those Morganas don't stand a chance.
@BATTLE
One, two, one, two! Up the river and down to the bayou!
Getting ready for your exercise again?
Of course! I want to keep myself in top shape.
Mind if I join you on your run?
Oh, I'm not going for a dash this time. Rather, I have decided upon a swim.
Swimming?
Yep. It's a more aerobic exercise, and rather useful out here. Care to take part?

Fields.MenuText: Aren't you already swimming, technically?
Just to check, you do know how to swim, right?
Out here may not be the best place for a swim.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but this will be something novel. Besides, my ship cannot go beneath the surface. Unless a Morgana has her way with us, I suppose... which I certainly do not want!
Of course I know... or at least, I should. It can't be much different from how a boat traverses the water, right?
We're fighting a war, Captain. Danger is merely an accessory like my parasol, and I've grown accustomed to it.
Well, what do you hope to find under the waves?
Sadly not pie, but something? But... darn. That will have to wait for another day, now.
I see them, too, Missy.
@BATTLE
Mississippi, where are you? We need to stay alert on our patrol!
In back here, Captain. Just give me a sweet second.
Now what are you up to?
Why, simply drying out my dress and hair properly. That jetsam we encountered earlier splashed all over me!
You complain about being wet, yet you sail on the water and want to go swimming.
That's... different.
Perhaps a little. You still surprise me.
How so?

Fields.MenuText: How can you be so delicate sometimes, but headstrong the next moment?
Is it really worth investing so much effort into your appearance?
Sometimes you're a bit... inconsistent.

Fields.DialogueText: It's all a matter of responsibility. I have the duty to uphold my dignity as a lady, yet also my service as a war vessel.
It's the little things that make the most difference, Captain. If we let go of the trivial things, then how can we take responsibility with the momentous things?
I am who - or what - I am. Surely, what does one expect when you put a lady in a boat, or a boat in a lady?
Well, I suppose that's just the way you are, Missy. At least it always keeps me guessing.
Morgana forces approaching. Time to crush them to dust!
Let's get to the bridge!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You've been secretive lately, so let me guess... How's the show coming along, Missy?
I've found some promising acts. Oh, and I just thought of something else... what if we did a short exercise program?
Like running?
Or lifting weights or something, the kind doesn't matter too much. I think it would help encourage people to be more active, don't you?

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure it'll fit with the rest of the program?
I guess that's one way to ''actively'' engage the audience.
Who's going to run the exercise routine?

Fields.DialogueText: It could! Some forms of exercise have a graceful flair to them.
I was just going to have us demonstrate, but if we involve the audience, then they'll really get into it.
Well, I was hoping that the two of us could. But really, we should try to rope in as many troops as we can, to make a lasting impression on everyone.
It's a good idea, but it may not work within a show. Maybe you could work to expand your exercise routines into a program of their own.
That's something to consider. I just want to find ways to make the show lively and exciting.
With you at the helm, there's no need to worry about that.
That's lovely of you to say, Captain. Now then, shall we practice another exercise I fancy?
@BATTLE
That is your style, I admit.
Just as long as they aren't too exhausted to appreciate the rest of the show.
"Wayyyyy down upon the Mis-sy RivERRRRR!"
Bravo!
Why, thank you. How was it?
Great! But isn't the song about the "Swanee River"?
Yes, but that doesn't even go through Mississippi. I thought this would be classier.
Whatever floats your boat, I suppose.
I think so. Say, Captain, I wanted to ask, where do you want to go with our act?
What do you mean?
Well, when I first suggested a duo performance, I imagined something a bit... intimate. But since we're friends, I thought I should leave the exact details up to you.

Fields.MenuText: If we stick to our different responsibilities in the act, things should be fine.
It's perfectly all right for friends to work closely together, so our act should still work out.
If you don't want to do a combination act, we don't have to.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. We each bring our own talents to the fray. I'd like us to work closely as friends.
I agree... there's no reason to worry.
No, I want to. I just... wasn't sure how you felt about it.
Captain, would you care to practice now?
Unfortunately, it will have to wait. Reconnaissance says we'll have enemy contacts coming into range any moment.
Maybe we can pull down the curtains on at least one of those monsters!
@BATTLE
You're my friend, Missy. I know it means a lot to you, and it means a lot to me as well.
I appreciate the sentiment.
I heard what you did there.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you. I was very proud of it.
I promise, completely accidental.

Fields.DialogueText: Mm-hm.
Anyway. Things are coming along well?
Planting flowers?
Lovely magnolias, to be precise. My favorite flower.
Don't magnolias come from trees?
Yes, but I took a few cuttings to grow. They look divine, don't they?
They certainly are pretty, but will they be all right out here at sea?
No reason to fret, Captain. They're quite hardy for flowers. We just need to shower them with love.

Fields.MenuText: I think I read somewhere that the flowers actually came before the first pollinators, and inspired the process.
Beautiful, yet strong. Just like you.
You have a really caring heart, don't you?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that makes sense. The Lord created plants two days before flying things, after all. I aim to be like such a flower someday, inspiring new life that spreads across the world.
Thank you, Captain. It is my flower, after all. I look to it for the passion and inspiration that drives me forth, as a lady and as a soldier.
It is more than my duty. I love knowing that I can nurture and protect those around me, like a willow's shade on a hot day.
It looks like a few of them are starting to blossom.
Yes, they are. It's enchanting, seeing them bloom, isn't it? I like to think that we're flowers as well, blossoming with new hope to share with everyone.
If we're the flowers, I suppose that makes the Morganas the weeds. Well, time to clean up the garden a little.
@BATTLE
Captain, Captain!
What is it, Missy? Did you find something?
Yes, another splendid event we can host!
... Did I sleep through the last one?
No, no, I still want to do the showboat, but I thought of something else that would be wonderful... A country fair!
A country fair?
County or country, it doesn't matter, but I think it would be amazing. We could have all sorts of displays, and people could enter different contests. What do you say?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure if we'll be able to stay in one part of the globe for long, much less a county, while we're at sea.
Don't those events involve a lot of livestock?
I suppose a major attraction will be your cooking?

Fields.DialogueText: No matter. We can make our own fleet county at sea. There's never been a Mississippi county that was actually part of Mississippi, so we can start now. Or how about Captain's County?
No matter. I'm sure we can round up a bunch. Sheep, cattle, horses, polecats, alligators...
But of course! Some of my best recipes, though I'd like to also see some from you and the other Belles.
Okay, Mississippi, we can try to organize a fair. But do you think we can manage all of this, combined with the show?
Sure, if we put our minds to it. And bless your heart, I noticed you said ''we.''
Naturally. We're partners, aren't we?
Of course! It really makes me happy that you want to work with me on this.
@BATTLE
That sounds like it would turn into a circus.
*ALARM*
Well, looks like we have some guests. Let's not keep them waiting - there's no excuse for bad manners, no matter the situation
Oh, Captain!
Oh, Missy! What is it this time?
What, don't you trust me?
I trust that you always have some new idea you want to spring on me.
It's just a little ol' thing...
Well, I can't say I dislike your ideas. They're always colorful, to be sure. Entertain me.
I was thinking about the show-
You mean another act or something?
Not exactly. I want to do a play. Some nice, proper theater at sea for our fine audience.
Sounds interesting.
I know. Do you think it could work?

Fields.MenuText: Couldn't a play qualify as a full show on its own?
How about something comedic?
Why not a full opera?

Fields.DialogueText: I know, but I want to do it all. At least for the opening show - once we take it ''on the tide'' so to speak - we can alternate the content between performances.
That could be nice. Cultured entertainment is fulfilling, but so is just enjoying yourself and laughing on a summer day.
A little too highbrow for my tastes. Besides, we don't want to bore the audience. This is supposed to be fun, first and foremost.
If we can find enough actors and actresses, I guess we could do a play.
Thank you! This will be wonderful, I promise you that.
But it will take a lot of work. And remember, we have a war to fight.
How could I possibly forget those nasty clouts?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
The show, not the fair.
Correct! I was thinking about adding a little something extra in.
So, any luck finding suckers... I mean people... interested in being part of the play?
And, no, I'm still working on that. But the first order of business should be determining what the play is. The play's the thing, as they say.
Any particular standouts among the candidates?
Not... really. Nothing strikes my fancy. It's tough to focus in the middle of a war like this.

Fields.MenuText: How about the Twelfth Night?
Maybe Porgy and Bess?
If you're getting too overloaded, maybe you should take a step back and relax for a bit.

Fields.DialogueText: By the old Bard himself? That could work... I wonder what I would look like dressed as a man? Or you as a maid?
That would be something, wouldn't it? It would have that Southern charm to it. Only problem is that it's in Carolina and not good ol' Mississippi.
Perhaps you're right. Between the fair and the show and the play, I have so much to do. A lady should have time to recline and recouperate, you know.
Sorry, Captain, but I still can't decide. I guess we'll just have to set aside the play for now.
Maybe not. What if we just did a one-act performance as part of the show?
That's it! Perfect as a peach pie! Thank you, Captain! You're always helping me give direction to my dreams.
Now that's just giving me too much - okay, I know that look on your face.
I wonder if the Morganas enjoy plays... No matter! If they want a tragedy, we'll make sure it ends on a happy note for the rest of us at least.
@BATTLE
Can't say I know myself.
*ALARM*
I note your lack of faith and I graciously choose to ignore it.
Good job getting through the last battle.
Thank you. That reminds me, I wanted to talk to you about the play. Since it's going to be folded in with the show, I was thinking of reformatting our approach to it.
To what, the play or the show?
Both, in a fashion. You see, I was thinking that we make our duo performance the play.
I suppose it would consolidate things a bit.
We would need to cut down the number of actors to fit with the time constraints anyway, and I think we could manage it with just the two of us.

Fields.MenuText: Just as long as we bring in some of the stuff we already had in mind for our act.
That sounds great!
Sure, but let's figure out the actual play first.

Fields.DialogueText: Okay, we can work with that.
I'm glad you like the idea. Let's do our best with it!
Good point. It's no good counting your chickens when you still need to box up the coop.
Well, then, we should get on with figuring out the play and rehearsing. Opening night will come along before we know it.
Time just goes in a blur these days, doesn't it?
It sure does.
And here comes another demand on our time... I sense Morganas approaching, Captain.
@BATTLE
Uh-huh. For the record, when I was joking about getting suckers to act, it was because I knew somehow we were going to end up here.
Yes, yes, you're very clever. But what do you think?
So, have you found a good, one-act play for us?
No. It's tricky finding one that's just right. But I've been thinking...
And?
I don't know. Maybe I should try to write an act myself?

Fields.MenuText: How much experience do you have with theater?
Well, as long as it helps people laugh their troubles away.
Just make sure that it helps inspire people.

Fields.DialogueText: Not much. But it's the thought that counts, right?
Yes, a comedy would be a hoot and a half!
I hope the whole show reaches everyone out there. If we all feel that spirit of determination, we can push through and bring an end to this war.
Can you get it done? It seems like a lot of work.
Well, I'll do my best. And if the worst comes, we just have to get on stage and put our hearts into it.
Out of curiosity, what sort of original story do you have in mind for it?
How about something ripped from the headlines? The title could be, "Morganas! Morganas! Morganas!"
Huh? What kind of play would that be?
The kind we're about to star in, Captain. Enemy ships coming in fast!
@BATTLE
You sounded excited when you paged me on the loudspeaker, Missy. Did you have a breakthrough?
Inspiration finally responded to my invitation, Captain! Imagine this... a comedy... about a magnolia tree.
I'm willing to be convinced.
Excellent! She's caught in a storm and drifts out to sea, where she ends up on a pirate ghost ship - that's where you come in - and together we search for buried treasure!
That's... unique.
Well... What do you really think?

Fields.MenuText: The magnolia is a nice bit of symbolism.
This is really your story, isn't it?
So I'm the ship, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: I got the idea from those flowers I grew.
It truly is. In any case, our stories aren't over yet, so this will be just another chapter in it.
The perspective will do you some good! Your part is a mix between pirate captain and the ship itself.
Well, then, the next step is the script and then rehearsing, right?
Actually, I was thinking that we can just improvise on the stage. Think you're up to it?
Not sure, but I'll try my best to... improvise.
That's what has kept us ahead of the Morganas so far.
Then let's make sure it stays that way.
@BATTLE
Couldn't make your mind up, huh?
As far as I'm concerned, you'll always be my captain.
*ALARM*
Mississippi? Anybody seen our Belle?
Zzzz...
There you are. Mississippi, wake up!
Zzzz... Huh? What? Oh my stars, Captain! I was just...
I thought you said that Belles didn't need to sleep.
But it's still nice to try. There's been so much to do the last few days that I wanted to take a nap.

Fields.MenuText: Don't sleep too long. We need to stay alert.
Sleep well. We need you in top condition for the coming battles.
That's a cute teddy bear.

Fields.DialogueText: Will do. Just give me eleven more minutes.
Understood. If I can get the hang of napping, I'll be at full strength in no time.
She sure is, isn't she? Always good for a cuddle.
Just keep one eye open, okay? We don't know when the Morganas will attack.
Really? Is that how it's done? I suppose I could try that.
*ALARM*
There may be no rest for those devils, but they could at least be polite enough to let the rest of us do so.
@BATTLE
Figure of speech, Mississippi...
Well, the Morganas don't exactly have a sense of hospitality, do they?
Mississippi, are you - ouch!
I'm sorry Captain! Did that hurt?
I'm fine. It was just a little poke. But may I ask why you have a bunch of cacti in here?
I found a few of them the last time we were on leave. Don't you think they make darling decorations?
Unconventional booby traps for sailors, you mean?
Honest-to-goodness, I really am sorry about that! I plan to only place them in areas where they will be out of the way. May I please have your permission?

Fields.MenuText: Why cacti, of all things?
Well, maybe we could use them against a Morgana.
I'm just worried about someone getting hurt.

Fields.DialogueText: They remind me of myself. They have an affection for proper climates, have a lovely appearance when they bloom, and yet are hardy and sharp when pushed.
That would be quite amusing. Sadly, I fear that they would not appreciate our gift.
I suppose you're right. I don't wish to put my sailors at risk.
... Maybe this wasn't such a good idea. Please accept my apologies, Captain.
No harm done. And you are free to pursue your own cactus plantation as long as you keep it confined to your own quarters.
Understood. You know, I don't see why people don't like cactuses more. They look so lovely.
Probably the flesh-piercing needles.
Oh, please, don't be a dandelion. Getting poked by a prickly cucumber isn't much worse than rolling in the hay, or so I've heard.
@BATTLE
Now for those Morganas, the ones coming over the horizon... they can really sting if you let them.
I'm sitting at the top of the world...
You look happy.
I procured some catfish for the galley, and I'm going to fry it up!
That sounds delicious. Hey, isn't that cactus there, too?
I thought I'd try to cook it as a second dish.

Fields.MenuText: You remembered to pull out the needles, right?
I've heard that they're delectable, so I'm optimistic.
Catfish, Cacti, Cooking... have a ''C'' theme going?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't fret. I've already taken care of it. You're safe, Captain.
Trust me, it will be delicious when I'm through.
That is a funny coincidence, isn't it? Hey, Captain! ''Cact-fish.'' Get it?
So how long until it's ready?
I could whip it up in a flash, but first we need to fry some Morganas for the first course.

Fields.MenuText: You detected Morganas? I don't enjoy fighting on an empty stomach.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll cook you something worthy of the wait, Captain. Hold onto that.
@BATTLE
That's charming.

Fields.MenuText: *sigh* I'm more of an entree kind of person.

Fields.DialogueText: Brrr!
The wind is really getting to you, huh?
If we had a day this cold back home, people would call for a state of emergency.
Well, we're out here on the ocean, and it gets windy.
I know, but it still makes me shiver to the bones.

Fields.MenuText: Here, this blanket might help a little.
Don't frown! I'd hate to see your face freeze that way in this cold.
Want to do some exercises to warm up?

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, the blanket's big enough for the both of us! Cuddle up, Captain. It would be ungallant to leave my best friend out in the cold.
Trying to cheer me up, Captain? Well, it worked like a charm. I'm strong, and I'll take this itty bitty breeze with a smile.
Sure. That would be good. Let's get to it!
Thank you for trying to help.
No problem. It's an officer's duty.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Why, thank you!
After you.
Beautiful day for sailing, eh, Mississippi?
Most positively! Another lovely day at sea.
Until we bump into a Morgana.
Oh, a small price to pay for being out in the open waters, sailing the ocean blue!
The sea feels like a second home to me.

Fields.MenuText: Must be quite a chore keeping track of the different rooms in your home, then.
What exactly makes water so appealing to you?
It really is kind of wonderful out here time to time, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Captain! Well, I suppose it would be a hassle for you, but for a swift swimmer like me it is a piece of butterscotch pie.
It's who I am. I am the mother of water, after all! A graceful and kindly maiden who can be swift and merciless against evil.
Yes. I just want to sail into the horizon on days like this, and see what blessings God has in store.
A shame that weather like this never lasts for long. Best be ready for another ghost ship...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
And how are your actual swimming practices coming along?
Sssh! Don't remind me. Just enjoy the fine weather today, all right?
The horizon's clear for now, Mississippi. If we have a few minutes, maybe we should rehearse our act for the show.
Fun! Then let's begin. Ahem.
Um... I... erm...
Missy, what's wrong?
I... haven't actually done this before. I only remember watching performances like this. And were they even real? Oh! It's no good! Let's just call this off.

Fields.MenuText: "Avast ye, mateys! Why dare ye to board me?" Psst! Now do your line.
Don't be scared, Missy. You can do this.
You're a magnolia, Missy. A proud flower on the river. Just be yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: "Captain..." Um, I mean, "Please, Ghost Ship! Let me stay for but a fortnight!"
You're right. Let's start from the top! "I'm a young tree, and have just come over..."
Right! "Ah, I feel the sun upon my boughs, as my roots dip in the shining waters!"
Well, it's a start.
I just needed to get into the river to start flowing with the current.
Considering that we talk with each other all the time, doing the same on stage won't be much different, right?
Yes. Above all, let's just enjoy ourselves. That is what this show and dream is all about.
Certainly. The whole show is going to be a blast.
I do believe it will be, Captain! And actually, maybe we could get some other Belles involved. I wanted to handle most of this by myself, but it's good to have company.
If it helps you feel more comfortable on the stage, go right ahead.
Well, a little birdie told me that Arizona might be interested in this sort of thing... But anyways, where were we?
*ALARM*
Starting an improvisational act with at least one Morgana cameo?
They should be honored to be part of our show... even if they go out with a bang.
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
Dang! No. No!!!
Missy, what's wrong?
One of my guns backfired. Why didn't I check it?! I was all worried about sweeping up the passageways, musical numbers, gardening... I should have... I should have...
Mississippi, calm down and report. What's your status? Is anyone hurt?
Many of our crew were close to the explosion and need some kind of care. And the Morganas aren't giving up! I'm... I'm so sorry for letting you down, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: Get a hold of yourself, Mississippi. You're a proud American warship! You gonna let those things out there see you sweat?

Fields.DialogueText: I won't surrender that easily! Even if I mess up, I will still fight to the end, and make my home state proud!
I'm still here for you, Missy, no matter what. So, ready for another round?
You betcha! Thanks for keeping your faith in me, Captain.
No problem. Keep it steady, and we can make it through the fight.
Right! Now to make the Morganas kiss my grits.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Make sure that the injured are taken care of, and then get back to the battle. We can't go dead in the water here.

Fields.DialogueText: Right. No time to faint like a willow. I'll get to it on the double!

Fields.MenuText: What's done is done. Accept your mistake, and move forward.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I will, Captain. If I reprimand myself now, I'll just make things worse. Time to make up for my blunder!
No!
NO!
... Right.
Missy, the fleet's ready to move in for the assault. Are you ready?
Almost! Let me wipe my dress like that and... there! Everything is pristine for the battle.
Excellent.
The sun always beats down on us, but the most we can do is stand strong in its light. We just have to not give up.

Fields.MenuText: Agreed. Give it everything you've got.

Fields.DialogueText: Never fear. I'll gracefully tear through them as easily as a lazy stroll through the cottonwoods.
Don't get me wrong, Mississippi. I'm not giving up.
We'll find our peace in the future, I know it. For now, let us do our duty to the world once more.
Full steam, Missy!
Virtute et armis! By valor and arms, let us shine light into this dark abyss!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I wonder, though, even if the Morganas are completely destroyed, will the struggle truly end?

Fields.DialogueText: With God's grace, the bonds that we have built in this trial will endure forever.

Fields.MenuText: There has to be an end to this. We have to finish this someday, or we'll just collapse from exhaustion before we're through.

Fields.DialogueText: The future can be tricky to judge, just like a river or ocean. Sometimes your destination never comes into sight until the very end. We'll make it there together, Captain.
